properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions near the Richardson Mountains. Easterly winds of 100 km/h gusting to 120 are combining with loose snow to reduce visibility to 400 metres or less. This blizzard is expected to last through the weekend. Winds will ease slightly Sunday night but visibility may still be poor in blowing snow. Blizzard conditions will abate early next week. ### Travel is expected to be very difficult or impossible due to near-zero visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-14T10:33:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-13T18:34:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3224153163.2020
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Less than 1 millimetre of freezing precipitation is expected this morning. Freezing rain will change over to rain near midday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-14T02:29:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-13T10:30:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2734580972.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow at times heavy persists this evening. An additional 5 to 10 cm of snow is expected in addition of the snowfall amounts of 10 cm received since Saturday evening. Blowing snow is possible in areas exposed to the wind. Weather conditions will improve gradually overnight tonight. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Summary:

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for tonight. Snow briefly heavy at times is expected tonight in areas extending from near Marathon to Montreal River Harbour. Snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are likely with 10 to 15 cm possible in a few localities. Poor winter driving conditions from low visibility and accumulating snow on untreated highways are expected to develop this evening. Conditions are expected to improve by Monday morning after the snow tapers off to scattered flurries. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-14T12:45:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-13T20:46:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3119660470.2020
Area: Marathon - Schreiber, Wawa - Pukaskwa Park, Agawa - Lake Superior Park

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Storm surge warning Coastal flood warning issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Region on 2020-12-12. An intense low pressure system will cause moderate winds in the regions mentioned below. The combination of these winds and the fact that we are currently in a period of high amplitude tidal range could produce minor flooding along the coast near these localities, on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Standard Time). Quebec City: 2020-12-13, from 04:30 PM to 07:30 PM. ### Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-14T04:59:54-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chill values at Taloyoak are expected to drop to -55 tonight as the skies will remain clear with light northerly winds. Partly cloudy skies in Gjoa Haven and Kugaaruk will keep the temperatures slightly warmer. It will warm up slightly Monday afternoon, but temperatures will plummet again Monday evening giving windchill values well below -55 in Gjoa Haven, Kugaaruk, and Taloyoak. ### Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-14T12:30:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-13T20:31:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2099848481.2020
Area: Taloyoak

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected beginning Tuesday. Locations: coastal Labrador and the Eagle River area. Time span: Tuesday and Wednesday. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, and strong easterly winds are expected to spread across coastal Labrador on Tuesday. While it is too soon to provide specific details, the potential exists for significant snowfall mid week. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-14T11:47:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-13T19:48:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1480859415.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential winter storm mid week. Locations: Newfoundland. Time span: Tuesday and Wednesday. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 80 km/h with higher gusts likely along coastal areas. Remarks: A storm will track towards Newfoundland Monday night. While it is too soon to provide specific details, the potential exists for strong winds accompanied by significant amounts of snow or rain. Snow and snowsqualls are expected for western and northern Newfoundland, while mainly rain is expected in the east. Central areas may see a change from snow to rain throughout this event. Additional information will be provided as the details become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-14T11:20:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-13T19:21:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0878388329.2020

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Clear skies and relatively light winds will cause the temperature to plummet Sunday night to -40. Wind chill values will reach near -50 by Monday morning. Temperatures will warm up slightly Monday afternoon, and cloud cover on Monday night should keep the extreme cold from returning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-14T14:37:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-13T22:38:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0547093933.2020

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Conditions may be favourable for snow squalls to develop off of Lake Superior Monday afternoon and Monday evening. Snowfall amounts near 15 cm are possible. Poor winter driving conditions from sudden low visibility in bursts of heavy snow and blowing snow are possible beginning Monday afternoon. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-14T12:46:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-13T20:47:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1940527016.2020
Area: Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay, Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island
